item.title: Reimagine Project Constraints as a Blank Canvas
item.dc:creator: thedemo
item.content:encoded:
One communication is tricky. Jokes, sarcasm and irony dont translate easily through text, so your intent can easily be misunderstood.
While emojis and GIFs certainly help, theres still no sarcasm font, so you have to choose every word with thoughtfulness and care. Need a help desk that can scale with you as you grow? Click here to check out Help Scouts powerful new free plan! Thats why virtual tone is so important in customer service. You cant set communication guidelines with customers (like you can for internal company communication), so every word and exclamation point counts.
To demonstrate these challenges, and the solution we use on the Customers team at Help Scout, I'm teaching Leah on our People Ops team how to walk that line.
[caption id="attachment_6013" align="alignnone" width="700"] Photo by Ilona D.Veresk[/caption]

Lesson 1: More action, less apology

Wistia video thumbnail - School of Support: Episode 1 Intro1:10 Dont linger on your apology. Instead, focus your reply on action. Acknowledge the problem the customer is reporting, but spend most of your time focusing on what youre going to do about it. Say youre sorry when its genuine, empathize, then move on to solving the problem or giving them context to their issue. [caption id="attachment_6012" align="alignleft" width="700"] Photo by Ilona D.Veresk[/caption]

Reading List

Saying No to Customers How to say Sorry Why I Changed How I Apologize to Customers Lesson 2: Be direct Wistia video thumbnail - Episode 1: bug fix. When a customer reports a bug, theyre likely pretty frustrated. For both the initial report and your follow-up, cut to the chase and dont waste their time. Overtures, no matter how well intentioned, just delay the message, so keep your communication focused before adding any warm fuzzies.

For both the initial report and your follow-up, cut to the chase and dont waste their time.

Boost Customer Happiness with Exclamations and Emoticons Using GIFs for Better Support Lesson 3: Match your customers tone [caption id="attachment_6014" align="alignnone" width="700"] Photo by Ilona D.Veresk[/caption]

Wistia video thumbnail - Episode 1: formal

Matching tone is a way to let the customer know you are on their side. If a customer is formal, for example, hang back with the LOLs. If theyre more casual, relax your tone too. Mirroring builds rapport and puts your customer at ease, reducing the amount of interpretation needed to understand what youre trying to communicate.

item.title: Styleguide
item.dc:creator: thedemo
item.content:encoded:
You can add introduction text with larger font size and accent color. Wrap any paragraph with class bw-intro.
While emojis and GIFs certainly help, theres still no sarcasm font, so you have to choose every word with thoughtfulness and care. Need a help desk that can scale with you as you grow? Click here to check out Help Scouts powerful new plan! [caption id="attachment_6381" align="alignnone" width="1024"] Photo by Laurent Nivalle[/caption] Thats why virtual tone is so important in customer service. You cant set communication guidelines with customers (like you can for internal company communication), so every word and exclamation point counts.
To demonstrate these challenges, and the solution we use on Customers team Help Scout, I'm teaching Leah on our People Ops team how to walk that fine line.
  [caption id="attachment_6390" align="alignleft" width="728"] Photo by Laurent Nivalle[/caption]

Reading List

Saying No to Customers How to say Sorry Why I Changed How I Apologize to Customers Lesson 2: Be direct Wistia video thumbnail - Episode 1: bug fix. When a customer reports a bug, theyre likely pretty frustrated. For both the initial report and your follow-up, cut to the chase and dont waste their time. Overtures, no matter how well intentioned, just delay the message, so keep your communication focused before adding any warm fuzzies.

For both the initial report and your follow-up, cut to the chase and dont waste their time.

[caption id="attachment_6383" align="alignnone" width="1024"] Photo by Laurent Nivalle[/caption] Boost Customer Happiness with Exclamations and Emoticons Using GIFs for Better Support Lesson 3: Match your customers tone [caption id="attachment_6389" align="alignleft" width="1021"] Photo by Laurent Nivalle[/caption]

Wistia video thumbnail - Episode 1: formal

Matching tone is a way to let the customer know you are on their side. If a customer is formal, for example, hang back with the LOLs. If theyre more casual, relax your tone too. Mirroring builds rapport and puts your customer at ease, reducing the amount of interpretation needed to understand what youre trying to communicate.

Lesson 1: More action, less apology

Wistia video thumbnail - School of Support: Episode 1 Intro1:10 Dont linger on your apology. Instead, focus your reply on action. Acknowledge the problem the customer is reporting, but spend most of your time focusing on what youre going to do about it. Say youre sorry when its genuine, empathize, then move on to solving the problem or giving them context to their issue.
